item.title: Exploring Forbes 2018 List with forbesList package
item.description: Using forbesListR package We’ll access forbes list through forbesListR package. For more details see https://github.com/abresler/forbesListR. Let’s begin by loading the packages, calling the Forbes billionaires list, and formatting the data forbes_data <- get_year_forbes_list_data(list = "Billionaires", year = 2018) forbes_data_clean <- forbes_data %>% mutate(`Net worth (Bn USD)` = round(net_worth.millions/1000,2), Image = paste0('![](', url.image, ')')) %>% rename(Industry = industry, HQ = headquarters, Age = age, Name = name) %>% select(Name, Image, Age, `Net worth (Bn USD)`, Industry, HQ) forbes_data_clean$Age_group <- sapply(forbes_data_clean$Age, age_group) Let’s start by printing top 10 entries in the list forbes_data_clean %>% head(10) %>% kable(caption = "Top 10 in Forbes 2018") %>% kableExtra::kable_styling(bootstrap_options = "responsive") Table 1: Top 10 in Forbes 2018 Name Image Age Net worth (Bn USD) Industry HQ Age_group Jeff Bezos 55 112.
